facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1406 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1406 of 1969.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated April 17, 1969 of the Delhi High Court in Civil Writ No. 611 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 17, 1969 of the Delhi High Court in Civil Writ No. 611 of 1968.

facts.text: The order dated 5th July 1968 placed the appellant under suspension.

anchor.surface_text: challenges the order dated 5th July, 1968 placing the appellant under suspension.

facts.text: Appellant was appointed to the Indian Police Service in 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed to the Indian Police Service in the year 1935.

facts.text: Appellant was posted as Inspector General of Police of Andhra Pradesh on 1 November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: He was posted as Inspector General of Police of the State of Andhra Pradesh, on 1 November, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant was confirmed as Inspector General of Police, Andhra Pradesh in 1957.

anchor.surface_text: He was ,confirmed as Inspector General of Police, Andhra Pradesh in the year 1957.

facts.text: Appellant reached the age of 55 years on 14 May 1966.

anchor.surface_text: On 14 May, 1966, he reached the age of 55 years.

facts.text: Appellant continued to work as Inspector General of Police, Andhra Pradesh up to 1 August 1967.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, companytinued to work as Inspector General of Police, Andhra Pradesh up to 1 August, 1967.

facts.text: Appellant was posted as Special Inspector General of Police for the revision of Police Standing Orders after 1 August 1967.

anchor.surface_text: He was then posted as Special Inspector General of Police for the revision of Police Standing Orders.

facts.text: In 1967, Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh ordered Chief Secretary to make an enquiry regarding certain allegations against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Some time in the year 1967 the Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh ordered that the Chief -Secretary should make an enquiry with regard to certain allegations against the appellant.

facts.text: Chief Secretary recommended that Vigilance Commissioner of Andhra Pradesh be requested to look into the matter.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Secretary recommended that the Vigilance Commissioner in the State of Andhra Pradesh might be requested to look into the matter.

facts.text: Vigilance Commissioner advised enquiry by independent agency like Central Bureau of Investigation.

anchor.surface_text: The Vigilance Commissioner advised that the enquiry should be companyducted by an independent agency like the Central Bureau of Investigation.

facts.text: Central Bureau of Investigation made an enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Bureau of Investigation thereafter made an enquiry.

facts.text: Appellant was given allegations to answer, submitted explanation, and was examined by Central Bureau of Investigation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was given allegations to answer. The appellant submitted explanation and was examined.

facts.text: Central Bureau of Investigation made a report on the enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Bureau of Investigation made a report on the enquiry.

facts.text: Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs made order placing appellant under suspension on 11 July 1968.

anchor.surface_text: On 1 1 July., 1968 the Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs made an order placing the appellant under suspension.

facts.text: Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh was inimical to appellant since General Elections in 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Minister of the State of Andhra Pradesh was inimical and hostile to the appellant since the time of the General Elections in the year 1967.

facts.text: Investigation by Central Bureau of Investigation was conducted by persons hostile to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The investigation by the Central Bureau of Investigation was companyducted by persons who were hostile to the appellant.

facts.text: First Information Report dated 17 August 1967 under section 154 CrPC charging appellant with offences under Prevention of Corruption Act 1947 for period 1960 to 1967.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the appeal Mr. Solicitor General produced the companyrect companyy of the First Information Report dated 17 August, 1967 under section 154 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. It will appear from the report that the appellant was charged with offences under the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 and the time of occurrence was the period 1960 to 1967.

facts.text: Investigation, inquiry or trial relating to criminal charge against appellant is pending.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are that there was an investigation and the trial is awaiting relating to a criminal charge against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant failed to establish that Government acted mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has failed to establish that the Government acted mala fide.

facts.text: No allegation against any particular officer of Government of India about acting mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberallegation against any particular officer of the Government of India about acting mala fide.

facts.text: Order of suspension was made under sub-rule 3 of Rule 7.

anchor.surface_text: The order or suspension was made under subrule  3  and does number suffer from any vice of infringement of Rule 7.

facts.text: Affidavit filed by appellant in support of petition was not verified.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an affidavit in support of the petition. Neither the petition number the affidavit was verified.

facts.text: Affidavits filed in answer to appellant's petition were not verified.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavits which were filed in answer to the appellants petition were also number verified.

facts.text: Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh and other persons were not made parties.

anchor.surface_text: Neither the Chief Minister number any other person was made a party.

facts.text: Appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, fails and is dismissed.
the order of suspension was made under sub-rule 1 of Rule 7 of the All-India Service Appeal and Discipline Rules, 1955, and is, therefore, liable to be quashed.

concepts.interpretation: Requires initiation of disciplinary proceedings and satisfaction of Government that suspension is necessary; appellant contended order made under this but court held it was not.

concepts.unlisted_label: All India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955 Rule 7(1)

anchor.surface_text: 2 A member of the Service in respect of or against whom, an investigation, inquiry or trial relating to a criminal charge is pending may, at the discretion of the Government under which he is serving, be placed under suspension until the termination of all proceedings relating to that charge, if the charge is connected with his position as a Government servant or is likely to embarrass him in the discharge of his duties or involves moral turpitude.

concepts.interpretation: Allows suspension where criminal charge pending if connected to duties or moral turpitude.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-rule 3 of Rule 7 states that a member of the Service in respect of, or against whom, an investigation, inquiry or trial relating to a criminal charge is pending may, at the discretion of the Government

concepts.interpretation: Court held suspension order valid under this sub-rule as criminal investigation pending; no need for disciplinary proceedings.

holdings.text: The appellant has failed to establish that the Government acted mala fide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No specific allegation against any officer of Government of India; unverified affidavits inadmissible; Chief Minister not impleaded; neither mala fides nor collateral purpose proved.

holdings.text: There is no allegation against any particular officer of the Government of India about acting mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: There is no allegation against any particular officer of the Government of India about acting mala fide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant alleged against Chief Minister and others but not against GOI officers who made the order.

holdings.text: The order of suspension was made under sub-rule 3 of Rule 7 and does not suffer from any vice of infringement of Rule 7.

anchor.surface_text: The order or suspension was made under subrule 3 and does number suffer from any vice of infringement of Rule 7.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order recites serious allegations, prima facie case from CBI enquiry, necessity considering circumstances; no reference to sub-rule 1; criminal investigation pending.

holdings.text: There was an investigation and the trial is awaiting relating to a criminal charge against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are that there was an investigation and the trial is awaiting relating to a criminal charge against the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmed by First Information Report under CrPC s.154 charging offences under Prevention of Corruption Act; CBI conducted enquiry.

holdings.text: The affidavits of all the parties suffer from the mischief of lack of proper verification with the result that the affidavits should not be admissible in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the affidavits of all the parties suffer from the mischief of lack of proper verification with the result that the affidavits should number be admissible in evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Verification tests genuineness, authenticity, responsibility; essential for serious allegations like mala fides; unsafe to act on unverified affidavits.

holdings.text: In order to succeed on the proof of mala fides in relation to the order of suspension, the appellant has to prove either that the order of suspension was made mala fide or that the order was made for collateral purposes.

anchor.surface_text: In order to succeed on the proof of mala fides in relation to the order of suspension, the appellant has to prove either that the order of suspension was made mala fide or

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant neither alleged nor established either feature.

holdings.text: We are not concerned with the correctness and the propriety of the report. We have only to examine whether the order of suspension was warranted by the rule and also whether it was in honest exercise of powers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that the report of the Central Bureau of Investigation was made mala fide. The appellant appeared before the investigation authorities. We ate number companycerned with the companyrectness and the propriety of the report. We have only to examine whether the order of suspension was warranted by the rule and also whether it was in honest exercise of powers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order satisfied rule and honest exercise tests.

holdings.text: We have, therefore, left open the contention as to the Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, 1946 to enable the appellant to agitate that contention, if so advised, in the criminal trial.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that sanction for the trial is pending pursuant to the investigation under the First Information Report dated 17 August, 1967 the appellant did number want a decision on this point in this appeal because the appellant would raise that companytention in the criminal case. We have, therefore, left open the companytention as to the Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, 1946 to enable the appellant to agitate that companytention, if so advised, in the criminal trial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant did not press in this appeal; to be decided in criminal trial.

edges.explanation: The First Information Report explicitly charges the appellant with offences under the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947, triggering the Act's application.
The fact of the FIR under CrPC charging offences under the Act grounds the holding that there was an investigation and awaiting trial on a criminal charge.
The FIR dated 17 August 1967 constitutes the pending criminal investigation referenced in the issue about the suspension order under sub-rule 3 of Rule 7.
